trans-unit.source: Manipulate encoding tasks by customizing task presets
trans-unit.target: Manipulate encoding tasks by customizing task presets

trans-unit.source: The Azure Media Services Encoder allows you to pass custom preset files to Azure Media Encoder. This topic shows how to customize preset files in order to achieve the following tasks: overlay an image onto an existing video, control the output file names that the encoder produces, stitch videos.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Media Services Encoder allows you to pass custom preset files to Azure Media Encoder. This topic shows how to customize preset files in order to achieve the following tasks: overlay an image onto an existing video, control the output file names that the encoder produces, stitch videos.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Media Services Encoder allows you to pass custom preset files to Azure Media Encoder.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Media Services Encoder allows you to pass custom preset files to Azure Media Encoder.

trans-unit.source: This topic shows how to customize preset files in order to achieve the following tasks:
trans-unit.target: This topic shows how to customize preset files in order to achieve the following tasks:

trans-unit.source: overlay an image onto an existing video,
trans-unit.target: overlay an image onto an existing video,

trans-unit.source: control the output file names that the encoder produces,
trans-unit.target: control the output file names that the encoder produces,

trans-unit.source: stitch videos,
trans-unit.target: stitch videos,

trans-unit.source: encode presentations with mostly speech.
trans-unit.target: encode presentations with mostly speech.

trans-unit.source: By default, the Azure Media Encoder creates output filenames by combining various attributes of the input asset and the encoding process.
trans-unit.target: By default, the Azure Media Encoder creates output filenames by combining various attributes of the input asset and the encoding process.

trans-unit.source: Each attribute is identified using a macro as discussed below.
trans-unit.target: Each attribute is identified using a macro as discussed below.

trans-unit.source: The following is a complete list of the macros available for output file naming: Audio Bitrate - the bitrate used when encoding the audio, specified in kbps
trans-unit.target: The following is a complete list of the macros available for output file naming: Audio Bitrate - the bitrate used when encoding the audio, specified in kbps

trans-unit.source: Audio Codec the codec used for encoding audio, valid values are: AAC, WMA, and DDP
trans-unit.target: Audio Codec the codec used for encoding audio, valid values are: AAC, WMA, and DDP

trans-unit.source: Channel Count the number of audio channels encoded, valid values are: 1, 2, or 6
trans-unit.target: Channel Count the number of audio channels encoded, valid values are: 1, 2, or 6

trans-unit.source: Default extension – the default file extension
trans-unit.target: Default extension – the default file extension

trans-unit.source: Language the BCP-47 language code representing the language used in the audio.
trans-unit.target: Language the BCP-47 language code representing the language used in the audio.

trans-unit.source: This currently defaults to “und”.
trans-unit.target: This currently defaults to “und”.

trans-unit.source: Original File Name the name of the file uploaded into Azure Storage
trans-unit.target: Original File Name the name of the file uploaded into Azure Storage

trans-unit.source: StreamId – the stream ID as defined by the streamID attribute of the <StreamInfo> element in the preset file
trans-unit.target: StreamId – the stream ID as defined by the streamID attribute of the <StreamInfo> element in the preset file

trans-unit.source: Video Codec the codec used for encoding, valid values are: H264 and VC1
trans-unit.target: Video Codec the codec used for encoding, valid values are: H264 and VC1

trans-unit.source: Video Bitrate the bitrate used when encoding the video, specified in kbps
trans-unit.target: Video Bitrate the bitrate used when encoding the video, specified in kbps

trans-unit.source: These macros can be combine in any permutation to control the name of the files generated by the Media Services Encoder.
trans-unit.target: These macros can be combine in any permutation to control the name of the files generated by the Media Services Encoder.

trans-unit.source: For example, the default naming convention is:
trans-unit.target: For example, the default naming convention is:

trans-unit.source: The file naming convention is specified using the DefaultMediaOutputFileName attribute of the <linkText>Preset</linkText><title></title> element.
trans-unit.target: The file naming convention is specified using the DefaultMediaOutputFileName attribute of the <linkText>Preset</linkText><title></title> element.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: The encoder will insert underscores between each macro, for example, configuration above would result in a file name like: MyVideoH2644500kpbsAACundch2128kbps.mp4.
trans-unit.target: The encoder will insert underscores between each macro, for example, configuration above would result in a file name like: MyVideoH2644500kpbsAACundch2128kbps.mp4.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Media Services Encoder allows you to overlay an image (jpg, bmp, gif, tif), a video, or an audio track (*.wma, *.mp3, *.wav) onto an existing video.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Media Services Encoder allows you to overlay an image (jpg, bmp, gif, tif), a video, or an audio track (*.wma, *.mp3, *.wav) onto an existing video.

trans-unit.source: This functionality is similar to that of Expression Encoder 4 (Service Pack 2).
trans-unit.target: This functionality is similar to that of Expression Encoder 4 (Service Pack 2).

trans-unit.source: You can specify when the overlay will be presented, the duration the overlay will presented, and for image/video overlays where on the screen the overlay will appear. You can also have the overlays fade in and/or fade out. The audio/video files to overlay can be contained in multiple assets or a single asset. Overlays are controlled by the preset XML that is passed to the encoder. For a complete description of the preset schema, see Azure Media Encoder Schemas. Overlays are specified in the <MediaFile> element as shown in the following preset snippet:
trans-unit.target: You can specify when the overlay will be presented, the duration the overlay will presented, and for image/video overlays where on the screen the overlay will appear. You can also have the overlays fade in and/or fade out. The audio/video files to overlay can be contained in multiple assets or a single asset. Overlays are controlled by the preset XML that is passed to the encoder. For a complete description of the preset schema, see Azure Media Encoder Schemas. Overlays are specified in the <MediaFile> element as shown in the following preset snippet:

trans-unit.source: Overlays can be from a single or multiple assets.
trans-unit.target: Overlays can be from a single or multiple assets.

trans-unit.source: When creating video overlays using multiple assets, the overlay filename is specified in the OverlayFileName attribute using %n% syntax where n is the zero-based index of the input assets for the encoding task.
trans-unit.target: When creating video overlays using multiple assets, the overlay filename is specified in the OverlayFileName attribute using %n% syntax where n is the zero-based index of the input assets for the encoding task.

trans-unit.source: When creating video overlays with a single asset, the overlay file name is specified directly into the OverlayFileName attribute, as shown in the following preset snippets:
trans-unit.target: When creating video overlays with a single asset, the overlay file name is specified directly into the OverlayFileName attribute, as shown in the following preset snippets:

trans-unit.source: Example 1:
trans-unit.target: Example 1:

trans-unit.source: Example 2:
trans-unit.target: Example 2:

trans-unit.source: The location and size of the video overlay is controlled by the OverlayRect attribute.
trans-unit.target: The location and size of the video overlay is controlled by the OverlayRect attribute.

trans-unit.source: The content that is to be overlaid will be re-sized to fit this rectangle.
trans-unit.target: The content that is to be overlaid will be re-sized to fit this rectangle.

trans-unit.source: Opacity is controlled by the OverlayOpacity attribute.
trans-unit.target: Opacity is controlled by the OverlayOpacity attribute.

trans-unit.source: Valid values are 0.0 – 1.0, where 1.0 is 100% opaque.
trans-unit.target: Valid values are 0.0 – 1.0, where 1.0 is 100% opaque.

trans-unit.source: The overlay will be displayed at the time specified by the OverlayStartTime attribute and will end at the time specified by the OverlayEndTime attribute.
trans-unit.target: The overlay will be displayed at the time specified by the OverlayStartTime attribute and will end at the time specified by the OverlayEndTime attribute.

trans-unit.source: Both OverlayStartTime and OverlayEndTime should fall within the timeline of the source video.
trans-unit.target: Both OverlayStartTime and OverlayEndTime should fall within the timeline of the source video.

trans-unit.source: For more information about each overlay-specific attribute, please see Azure Media Encoder Schemas.
trans-unit.target: For more information about each overlay-specific attribute, please see Azure Media Encoder Schemas.

trans-unit.source: Audio overlays can be any supported audio file format, for example. For a complete list of supported audio file formats, see Formats Supported by the Media Services Encoder. Audio overlays are also specified in the <MediaFile> element as shown in the following preset snippet:
trans-unit.target: Audio overlays can be any supported audio file format, for example. For a complete list of supported audio file formats, see Formats Supported by the Media Services Encoder. Audio overlays are also specified in the <MediaFile> element as shown in the following preset snippet:

trans-unit.source: For audio overlays stored in multiple assets, the audio overlay filename is specified in the AudioOverlayFileName attribute using %n% syntax, where n is the zero-based index of the collection of input assets to the encoding Task.
trans-unit.target: For audio overlays stored in multiple assets, the audio overlay filename is specified in the AudioOverlayFileName attribute using %n% syntax, where n is the zero-based index of the collection of input assets to the encoding Task.

trans-unit.source: For audio overlays stored in a single asset the overlay filename is specified directly in the AudioOverlayFileName attribute.
trans-unit.target: For audio overlays stored in a single asset the overlay filename is specified directly in the AudioOverlayFileName attribute.

trans-unit.source: The AudioOverlayLayoutMode determines when the audio overlay will be presented.
trans-unit.target: The AudioOverlayLayoutMode determines when the audio overlay will be presented.

trans-unit.source: When set to “WholeSequence” the audio track will be presented during the entire duration of the video.
trans-unit.target: When set to “WholeSequence” the audio track will be presented during the entire duration of the video.

trans-unit.source: When set to “Custom” the AudioOverlayStartTime and AudioOverlayEndTime attributes determine when the audio overlay begins and ends.
trans-unit.target: When set to “Custom” the AudioOverlayStartTime and AudioOverlayEndTime attributes determine when the audio overlay begins and ends.

trans-unit.source: Both OverlayStartTime and OverlayEndTime should fall within the timeline of the source video.
trans-unit.target: Both OverlayStartTime and OverlayEndTime should fall within the timeline of the source video.

trans-unit.source: For more information on all of the audio overlay attributes, see the Azure Media Encoder Schemas.
trans-unit.target: For more information on all of the audio overlay attributes, see the Azure Media Encoder Schemas.

trans-unit.source: Audio overlays can be combined with video overlays as shown in the following preset snippet:
trans-unit.target: Audio overlays can be combined with video overlays as shown in the following preset snippet:

trans-unit.source: Once you have created a preset file you must do the following:
trans-unit.target: Once you have created a preset file you must do the following:

trans-unit.source: Upload your asset(s)
trans-unit.target: Upload your asset(s)

trans-unit.source: Load the preset configuration (Note: the code below assumes the Preset above.
trans-unit.target: Load the preset configuration (Note: the code below assumes the Preset above.

trans-unit.source: Create a job
trans-unit.target: Create a job

trans-unit.source: Get a reference to the Media Services Encoder
trans-unit.target: Get a reference to the Media Services Encoder

trans-unit.source: Create a task specifying the collection of input assets, the preset configuration, the media encoder, and the output asset
trans-unit.target: Create a task specifying the collection of input assets, the preset configuration, the media encoder, and the output asset

trans-unit.source: Submit the job
trans-unit.target: Submit the job

trans-unit.source: The following code snippet shows how to do these steps:
trans-unit.target: The following code snippet shows how to do these steps:

trans-unit.source: This snippet loads each asset sequentially for simplicity.
trans-unit.target: This snippet loads each asset sequentially for simplicity.

trans-unit.source: In production environments assets would be loaded in bulk.
trans-unit.target: In production environments assets would be loaded in bulk.

trans-unit.source: For more information on uploading multiple assets in bulk see [Ingesting Assets in Bulk with the Media Services SDK for .NET](media-services-dotnet-upload-files.md#ingestinbulk).
trans-unit.target: For more information on uploading multiple assets in bulk see [Ingesting Assets in Bulk with the Media Services SDK for .NET](media-services-dotnet-upload-files.md#ingestinbulk).

trans-unit.source: For complete sample code see <linkText>Creating Overlays with Media Services Encoder</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For complete sample code see <linkText>Creating Overlays with Media Services Encoder</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: When editing the Preset string, you must ensure the following:
trans-unit.target: When editing the Preset string, you must ensure the following:

trans-unit.source: For video/image overlays, the overlay rectangle must fit entirely within the dimensions of the source video
trans-unit.target: For video/image overlays, the overlay rectangle must fit entirely within the dimensions of the source video

trans-unit.source: The start and end time of the overlays should be within the timeline of the source video
trans-unit.target: The start and end time of the overlays should be within the timeline of the source video

trans-unit.source: If the preset XML contains a reference to ?OverlayFileName=”%n%”, then the InputAssets collection for the Tasks should contain at least n+1 Assets
trans-unit.target: If the preset XML contains a reference to ?OverlayFileName=”%n%”, then the InputAssets collection for the Tasks should contain at least n+1 Assets

trans-unit.source: The media services encoder provides support for stitching together a set of videos.
trans-unit.target: The media services encoder provides support for stitching together a set of videos.

trans-unit.source: Videos can be stitched together end-to-end or you can specify portions of one or both videos to be stitched together.
trans-unit.target: Videos can be stitched together end-to-end or you can specify portions of one or both videos to be stitched together.

trans-unit.source: The result of the stitching is a single output asset that contains the specified video from the input assets.
trans-unit.target: The result of the stitching is a single output asset that contains the specified video from the input assets.

trans-unit.source: The videos to be stitched can be contained in multiple assets or a single asset.
trans-unit.target: The videos to be stitched can be contained in multiple assets or a single asset.

trans-unit.source: Stitching is controlled by the preset XML passed to the encoder.
trans-unit.target: Stitching is controlled by the preset XML passed to the encoder.

trans-unit.source: For a complete description of the preset schema, see <linkText>Azure Media Encoder Schema</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For a complete description of the preset schema, see <linkText>Azure Media Encoder Schema</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Stitching is controlled within the <MediaFile> element as shown in the following preset:
trans-unit.target: Stitching is controlled within the <MediaFile> element as shown in the following preset:

trans-unit.source: For each video to be stitched, a <Source> element is added to the <Sources> element. Each <Source> element contains a <Clips> element. Each <Clips> element contains one or more <Clip> element that specifies how much of the video will be stitched into the output asset, by specifying a start and end time. The <Source> element references the asset on which it acts. The format of the reference depends on whether the videos to be stitched are in separate assets or in a single asset. If you want to stitch an entire video, simply omit the <Clips> element.
trans-unit.target: For each video to be stitched, a <Source> element is added to the <Sources> element. Each <Source> element contains a <Clips> element. Each <Clips> element contains one or more <Clip> element that specifies how much of the video will be stitched into the output asset, by specifying a start and end time. The <Source> element references the asset on which it acts. The format of the reference depends on whether the videos to be stitched are in separate assets or in a single asset. If you want to stitch an entire video, simply omit the <Clips> element.

trans-unit.source: When stitching videos from multiple assets, a zero-based index is used for the MediaFile attribute of the <Source> element to identify which asset the <Source> element corresponds to. The zero index is not specified, the <Source> element that does not specify a MediaFile attribute references the first input asset. All other <Source> elements must specify the zero-based index of the input asset to which it refers by using %n% syntax where n is the zero-based index of the input asset. In the preceding example the first <Source> element specifies the first input asset, the second <Source> element specifies the second input asset, and so on. There is no requirement that the input assets be referenced in order, for example:
trans-unit.target: When stitching videos from multiple assets, a zero-based index is used for the MediaFile attribute of the <Source> element to identify which asset the <Source> element corresponds to. The zero index is not specified, the <Source> element that does not specify a MediaFile attribute references the first input asset. All other <Source> elements must specify the zero-based index of the input asset to which it refers by using %n% syntax where n is the zero-based index of the input asset. In the preceding example the first <Source> element specifies the first input asset, the second <Source> element specifies the second input asset, and so on. There is no requirement that the input assets be referenced in order, for example:

trans-unit.source: This example stitches together portions of the second, the first, and the third input assets.
trans-unit.target: This example stitches together portions of the second, the first, and the third input assets.

trans-unit.source: Note that since each video is referenced by a zero-based index it is possible to stitch two videos together that have the same name.
trans-unit.target: Note that since each video is referenced by a zero-based index it is possible to stitch two videos together that have the same name.

trans-unit.source: Once you have created a preset file you must do the following:
trans-unit.target: Once you have created a preset file you must do the following:

trans-unit.source: Upload your assets
trans-unit.target: Upload your assets

trans-unit.source: Load the preset configuration
trans-unit.target: Load the preset configuration

trans-unit.source: Create a job
trans-unit.target: Create a job

trans-unit.source: Get a reference to the Media Services Encoder
trans-unit.target: Get a reference to the Media Services Encoder

trans-unit.source: Create a task specifying the input assets, the preset configuration, the media encoder, and the output asset
trans-unit.target: Create a task specifying the input assets, the preset configuration, the media encoder, and the output asset

trans-unit.source: Submit the job
trans-unit.target: Submit the job

trans-unit.source: The following code snippet shows how to do these steps:
trans-unit.target: The following code snippet shows how to do these steps:

trans-unit.source: This snippet loads each asset sequentially for simplicity.
trans-unit.target: This snippet loads each asset sequentially for simplicity.

trans-unit.source: In production environments assets would be loaded in bulk.
trans-unit.target: In production environments assets would be loaded in bulk.

trans-unit.source: For more information on uploading multiple assets in bulk see [Ingesting Assets in Bulk with the Media Services SDK for .NET](media-services-dotnet-upload-files.md#ingestinbulk).
trans-unit.target: For more information on uploading multiple assets in bulk see [Ingesting Assets in Bulk with the Media Services SDK for .NET](media-services-dotnet-upload-files.md#ingestinbulk).

trans-unit.source: For complete sample code see <linkText>Stitching with Media Services Encoder</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For complete sample code see <linkText>Stitching with Media Services Encoder</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: When stitching videos within a single asset, each video must have a unique name.
trans-unit.target: When stitching videos within a single asset, each video must have a unique name.

trans-unit.source: The videos are specified using the MediaFile attribute using the filename as the attribute’s value.
trans-unit.target: The videos are specified using the MediaFile attribute using the filename as the attribute’s value.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: This preset stitches parts of video1.mp4, video2.wmv, and video3.wmv into the output asset.
trans-unit.target: This preset stitches parts of video1.mp4, video2.wmv, and video3.wmv into the output asset.

trans-unit.source: The creation of the job and tasks is the same as stitching videos from multiple assets, you only need to upload a single asset as shown in the following code:
trans-unit.target: The creation of the job and tasks is the same as stitching videos from multiple assets, you only need to upload a single asset as shown in the following code:

trans-unit.source: When encoding video whose audio track contains mostly speech, the default encoder presets may cause background noise to be amplified in the encoded asset.
trans-unit.target: When encoding video whose audio track contains mostly speech, the default encoder presets may cause background noise to be amplified in the encoded asset.

trans-unit.source: This behavior is caused by the NormalizeAudio attribute being set to true.
trans-unit.target: This behavior is caused by the NormalizeAudio attribute being set to true.

trans-unit.source: To prevent the amplification of background noise, do the following:
trans-unit.target: To prevent the amplification of background noise, do the following:

trans-unit.source: Copy the contents of the encoder preset you are using into an XML file.
trans-unit.target: Copy the contents of the encoder preset you are using into an XML file.

trans-unit.source: The encoder presets can be found at: Azure Media Encoder Schemas
trans-unit.target: The encoder presets can be found at: Azure Media Encoder Schemas

trans-unit.source: Delete the NormalizeAudio attribute, it can be found near the top of the preset file under the <MediaFile> element:
trans-unit.target: Delete the NormalizeAudio attribute, it can be found near the top of the preset file under the <MediaFile> element:

trans-unit.source: <MediaFile DeinterlaceMode="AutoPixelAdaptive" ResizeQuality="Super" NormalizeAudio="True" AudioGainLevel="1" VideoResizeMode="Stretch">
trans-unit.target: <MediaFile DeinterlaceMode="AutoPixelAdaptive" ResizeQuality="Super" NormalizeAudio="True" AudioGainLevel="1" VideoResizeMode="Stretch">

trans-unit.source: Save the modified preset file to your local hard drive, and use code such as the following to encode with the custom preset:
trans-unit.target: Save the modified preset file to your local hard drive, and use code such as the following to encode with the custom preset:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Media Encoder XML Schema</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Media Encoder XML Schema</linkText><title></title>
